reviewText:
Early Access Review

I saw this game on the summer flash sale, and it looked interesting, so I scooped it up. Boy am I glad I did! This is a fantasic, little, indie, strategy game where you are managing a subway station. Your job is to lay down subway lines to connect the different stations and get the different shapes (people) to their desired destinations. It starts off slow and progressivley keeps adding more and more, so you really have to think about where to place the lanes to be the most efficient. It's super easy to learn, but will take some time to master, and it's absurdly addicting.

This is an early access game but complely 100% playable. There is no music/audio yet, but that will come out soon. They use a very minimalistic art syle, which adds to it's clean look and makes it easy to understand, however, a few things might need to be clarified. Hopefully they will add a small description for the different items you have to choose from between weeks. There are a few I'm not completly understanding what they do or how they work.

The beginning tutorial is very simple, although they do not show you how to move tracks or divert them. I kinda found that out by accident, so hopefully they will expand on a few of these things.

I also hope they make it possible to save some of your games/city tracks you have made in a future update.

Overall this is an awesome little game, that is well executed, and 100% worth the full asking price. 10/10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nMini Metro is that game that I've wanted to play since gradeschool when I doodled city maps and mass transit systems in my notebook margins.  I am utterly hooked on the early access release, and I'm very excited by the prospect of more maps and game modes.  Maxis regrettably stripped trains and subways (a.k.a. the fun parts) out of the Sim City franchise, and Dinosaur Polo Club has concentrated them in this addictive and stylish game. reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR - Mini Metro is a top-down iconographic map-planning and resource-management simulation in which you build a metro system that somehow manages to pop new stations up at an alarming rate.  Your only resource is time, and you will eventually lose - the satisfaction in this game comes from creating a well oiled machine.  I'd recommend it to anyone who enjoyed building transport networks on Simcity 4 or find themselves building all possible city improvements in Civ just because they like to see the city doing well.

This (as of writing) is a game in Beta, but still thoroughly enjoyable.  Your task is to create a metro network by facilitaing the transport of shaped passengers (circle, square, triangle, star etc) with the same shaped stations.  This is done by connecting the station shapes with a coloured transport line - a train will automatically carry passengers back and forth along the line's length.

The difficulty comes from the fact that each station can only so many passengers - and once a station has been full for 30 seconds, it's game over.  This becomes more and more likely as the map progressively bigger, more stations are added, and more shapes are included - your only tools against this are earned at the end of each week; more trains, more lines, and more carriages.  To throw one more spanner into the works, each map contains a river which can only be travered through the use of 'tunnels' - again, only to be earned at the end of each week.  This causes  for some very difficult decisions to be made about whether you should pick more trains to add to your system, or whether you're going to need to get over the river with one of your lines before the week is out.

The aesthetic mirror's the current London Underground colouring and angling - meaning that even when you end up losing the game, looking back over your map is a fairly satisfying experience.

I definitely recommend to anyone who enjoys intense resource management and optimising pathing; the skill in this game is in weighing up many different routes simultaneously and evaluating which is the best.  An oddly satisfying experience all the way through; one that will be even better once the music and sound effects have been added into the game.

reviewText: Very nice little optimization puzzle game. The screenshots alone don't really do it justice. Each level starts off easy but then gets gradually harder when more and more stations pop up and passengers start to appear in a quicker pace. After each in-game week you get to pick one of two perks, such as tunnels or a new locomotive. These choices are interesting, there's no right answer that works all the time. The game also forces you to make interesting choices all the time in the name of optimization. Shorten that crowded line, but make another one longer? Add a carriage here or a locomotive there? Recommended, especially right now when you can get it in the Humble Eye Candy Bundle along with some other nice games. :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Mini Metro, a strategy game by Dinosaur Polo Club that is so simple yet so fun, you’d think that they actually made a game equivalent to Sudoku.

The game revolves around you, a bunch of shapes that resemble stations, train lines and customers that look like shapes. You have to connect all the stations together and get all the passengers to where they want to be without the stations getting crowded. The maps slowly expand revealing more play area to which more stations open up for you to connect to. You can make numerous train lines or add more trains and carriages to existing lines to help transporting passengers.

There are numerous levels to play on, each with rivers where you have to make tunnels through, despite the limited supply. You get a train given to you every week and a choice of an extra tunnel, carriage or train line to get to help you win. Even though it looks easy, it isn’t really. They added an extra mode which is the equivalent of a sandbox mode, where the stations can get full of passengers but the game doesn’t end, this allows you to just build and deliver passengers as you please, while still working with the limited supplies. They plan on making another mode which will be hard-core, only for experienced players, more cities, customers but maybe less or normal amount of assets.

Mini Metro is In Early Access currently (time of review posting) and therefore isn’t finished, a simple game with lots to do. Despite the lack of music, there are big plans for the future and it’s exciting to imagine what comes next. The game comes with the ability to change between colour-blind mode and not colour-blind mode, meaning that players who have trouble with colours can still play the game. There is even a Day and Night mode that changes the colour of the game, white for day and black for night so it doesn’t hurt your eyes. These two features aren’t given often in games but should be added for those who need these options.

This game, despite its easy looks it is quite hard, and that’s something you don’t see much anymore, hard games that look easy. Dinosaur Polo Club have developed a game that is really fun and challenging, something that strategy game lovers need in their steam library.

I rate this game a 9/10. Not a 10 because of the lack of features, but since it’s an Early Access game, a couple more updates and it’ll be a 10/10.

There is even a Day and Night mode that changes the colour of the game, white for day and black for night so it doesn’t hurt your eyes. These two features aren’t given often in games but should be added for those who need these options.

This game, despite its easy looks it is quite hard, and that’s something you don’t see much anymore, hard games that look easy. Dinosaur Polo Club have developed a game that is really fun and challenging, something that strategy game lovers need in their steam library.

I rate this game a 9/10. Not a 10 because of the lack of features, but since it’s an Early Access game, a couple more updates and it’ll be a 10/10.

This is a game that makes you happy to quit in furstration.

While early access the game is very playable as it currently stands. You build a subway and if you make it through a week without overcrowding any station you get another locomotive and a choice of upgrade from between two items. You usually really need both and it makes it hard to pick.

Somewhere in week five you have a jump in diffcultly where you have to scramble to keep everything going. I save a carriage and a locomotive just for that hump. You keep growing and growing until you have a station overcrowd and you fail. I can usually go four or five games before I get furstrated with failing. I've played hours on the beta version before they came to early access. I was happy to play until I quit in furstration and come back to try again later.

There is supposed to be a zen mode coming. When that hits I'll be playing lots more.

The delevopers are very good about feedback. I mentioned my family needed a colorblind mode and they were very good about asking what would make it easier for us. I've seen where things I've suggested (that I'm sure others suggested too) have been implemented already.

This is early access done right. When it gets closer to finished I'll be buying this for a friend if they haven't given in and gotten it by then. And that's the best recommandation I can give a game.

Early Access Review

Mini Metro is a zen puzzle game with simple yet addictive gameplay that keeps players interested for hours. I had the good fortune of stumbling over Mini Metro whilst reading about one of the Ludum Dare competitions (26 I believe); the game is a successor to 'Mind the Gap' a game of a similar premise.

The simple design and user interface will no doubt sit well with players, although I do wonder why there was a shift from the old in game menu which in many ways--was simpler--a simple flick to the left of the screen would bring it up. The actual gameplay is very good. Your objective is to maintain your underground system for as long as possible without too much overcrowding. If a station incurs too much congestion for more than thirty seconds, game over.

I cannot be certain as the game is still in pre-release, but there seems to have been some nerfing of gameplay in the form of bonuses you acquire at the end of the week. You now gain a new train every Sunday but there seems to be a lack of station upgrades. One of the things I was expecting was more choice, rather than less.

Some features are currently unavailable but in the works; maps and music come to mind. I'm looking forward to seeing those implemented over time. I caution Dinosaur Polo Club about adding new maps as DLC though (I still see a fairly lackluster amount of additional maps to be unlocked as the game is updated), and I hope we as players are buying the full game, rather than half of it!

One last point of contention is the game's varied art style. Some maps are very minimalist such as London and Paris, with a plain white background. Others, such as Cairo and New York are yellower and although this is a very very small point, I can't tell if this inconsistency is good or bad yet.

Over all Mini Metro is a solid game, especially for the price, well worth picking up!

8.5/10

reviewText:
Simple, Elegant, and Wonderful.

It's incredibly satisfying to create an efficient Metro system, even if the game is trying it's hardest to make your perfect system crumble under the demand. The controls are not completely explained, but five seconds of fiddling will allow you to figure it out. Other than that, everything's pretty intuitive. There's also plenty of maps available for you to work around, so there's damn near infinite replayability.

The developers did an excellent job.

Nailed it. This game is a wonderful blend of zen meditation and frantic route micromanagement. Just when you've settled in to a comfortable state with a well maintained line, you're given just a little more chaos to keep going. Wonderful! Best $10 I've spent in a long, long time.

Without completely redrawing everything in late game, I have not figured out a way to not make my maps zig-zag central.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of today, sept. 4th, 2015, Mini Metro is still in development. But it's already a fully playable (and enjoyable) game.

Mini Metro is a minimalist game, in the sense that:
- the goal is simple (keep your metro network working as fluidly as possible)
- the gameplay elements are simple (as time goes on, you gain more lines, train, tunnel...)
- the ergonomics are simple (draw a line between two stations and you've built a new metro line ; click and drop a train on a line and it'll immediately work on its own schedule)
- the look is simple (as you can see, the visuals are inspired by subway maps you can find all around the world)

But a minimalist game isn't a simple game. Each station has a specific shape. Imagine that a circle represents a residential district and that a triangle represents a business area. Passengers will then tend to go from a circle to triangle. And back. But as time goes, new shapes appear. And it really feels like if a city was blooming before your eyes. Again, imagine that a square is a commercial district, a star is a tourist area,  a diamond is an airport... Some of the shapes will appear in large numbers and close together. Others will be scarce but will be a favorite destination from all around the map. Again, just like in a real blooming city.

Add to that the fact that a dozen of real life cites are present in the game, each with a different feel, different tools, different obstacles.

To put it simply, the game is already perfect as it is. But it's still quite hard to explain and you really have to experience how it works, for it's both a very stressing and demanding game and a most contemplative and artistic pice of work.

Got it of this weeks Humblebundle after having it on my wishlist for quite some time.

I really like the atmosphere delivered with this game. Lovely sound-design and beautiful minimalistic visuals. Even though, from an outside point of view, it seems to get boring quickly it really manages not to when playing. Different levels, challenges & difficulties make it quite addicting due to the effort that has to go in planning your metro-systems. Fantastic job DPC, never thought I'd spend so much time in a simulation game!

How long can you keep the city moving?

Mini Metro's distinct levels--all inspired by real-world metro lines--definitely have deep nuances that affect your tactics for each and reward your experimentation and practice.

It's a lot like Flight Control, except more complex.

I love the meditative, minimalist aesthetic, especially with Night Mode enabled. FEZ composer Disasterpeace has crafted a lush, warm, subdued soundscape full of soft sines and small clocks that grows, shrinks, or shifts dynamically in response to your actions based on conditions in the game. Though even at full volume on my laptop, it wasn't loud enough for me.

At their core, simulation and management games are about optimizing a particular workflow or mastering a certain system as best as you can. Mini Metro falls into that category, even loosely--just on a smaller, less permanent scale. I admit, a larger and lasting scale of some kind would be even more interesting here, but it shares these traits of starting all over" with both score-chaser Arcade games and procedurally-generated Roguelike games.

Yet even with all its depth and variations
date: the gameplay itself is eventually too simple to be this repetitive
recommended: and too repetitive to be this simple. I guess that makes it more suited to being used as a palette cleanser between games or between life
hoursPlayed: once you've played past using it as a game. Hence the inclusion of a Daily Challenge.\n\nOverall

A very enjoyable, minimlist, puzzle game with a great aesthetic. The game offers a very fair gradient for gradually increasing the challenge while offering its players plenty of variety. With daily challenges, a nice selection of maps, and some very challenging achievements, this game provides lots of entertainment for the cost.\n\n

Mini Metro is by far one of my favourite games. You're given the challenge of building a metro system that successfully links people to the destinations of their choices without overwhelming the network or resulting in waiting too long at any one station. It's remarkably zen but also remarkably challenging... and I can't help but love to play this game!\n\nI particularly love the daily challenges which provide their own constraints but which can only be attempted once.
This game is a minimalist masterpiece.

Mini Metro is a fun minimalist strategy/puzzle game. Unlike many strategy games, each run lasts maybe 20-30 minutes, so it's great for playing one sitting at a time. You can pause whenever you like, so even when it gets tough it's not heavily stressful or anything. Combined with the dynamic soundtrack by Disasterpeace (you might know his music from Fez), it's a lovely game great for when you want to sit back, relax, and play a quick game.
Pretty funny game.

Beautiful and relaxing minimalist style matched with the frustration of overcrowding stations; despite the abstract and simple look it can become quite challenging to create an efficient metro map. Each city map has a unique pace, layout and metro elements to build with and you get three different game modes -- normal, endless, extreme. With an element of randomness added, no two games are the same. The subtle sounds effects are lovely as well.
Early Access Review\n\nSimple, Fun, and easy to run. I will say don't have high expectations, exactly what you see and nothing more, but still definately worth it.

Randomly spawned subway builder... optimize routes under ever-changing conditions. Check it out on their site if you want to try it out, but it's definitely worth the $10 to have access to more maps, nice music, different game modes, and support the developers. A great 20-minute game that leaves you wanting to play one" more."

After 23 hours and 58% achievement completion I had to delete this because I could work for 2 days. I dare to think what my productivity would be if I had this on phone.
Also, when Extra Credits said that it's a game you can play for 5 minutes or 5 hours... ♥♥♥♥ never have I dreamed that in less than a busy week I would play almost 24 hours.
Beware.

Also the metro was retired completely due to overcrowding. LOL. I wish it would happen in my country.

reviewText: This is a puzzle game I sincerely enjoyed. The mechanics of the game offer a depth which takes a long time to master, but is really easy to get into. The game uses minimalistic aesthetics which work really well, it doesn't overwhelm you with information but it still gives you everything you need to know to have an enjoyable experience.

An extremely simple but thoroughly enjoyable puzzle game.

Even though the UI and mechanics could be described in a couple of sentences, the complexities build up and intelligent planning is required to do well.

Definitely worth it if you want something casual to pass the time.

I bought Mini Metro when it was in Early Access for the first two or three months. I loved it, but there was a lot missing, which was expected for such an early version of the game. I forgot about for a long time, and when I remembered how the game was fun, I decided to check it out, since it was officially released. The game is great! It's pretty casual, the sounds are great (and I personally love how each new line has it's own sounds), and there are almost no problems, the only one I've encountered in 3.8 hours of game was that the sound glitched and turned into a one-tone buzz that was only fixed by restarting the game. I definitely recommend this if you appreciate casual strategy games.

reviewText: This game is a minimalist masterpiece.

A very enjoyable, minimlist, puzzle game with a great aesthetic. The game offers a very fair gradient for gradually increasing the challenge while offering its players plenty of variety. With daily challenges, a nice selection of maps, and some very challenging achievements, this game provides lots of entertainment for the cost.\n\n

This is an elegant puzzler that has you constructing stylized subway lines in big cities and avoiding overcrowding at stations for as long as possible. There's not much else to it other than daily challenges with leaderboards, a mode that makes all your tracks permanent and a mode that disables terminal overcrowding. It's kind of like if Train Valley was a survival game.\n\nThe two main problems are that the music (which is automatically generated from train movement and passenger sounds) might get grating after a while, and stations popping up seemingly randomly enough that games are as much up to chance as they are up to your on-the-spot problem solving ability. That last one's not so much of a problem if you can handle stress and are good at performing triage, but Cities in Motion this ain't. I do recommend this - I can see it being something you play while you're commuting yourself. Bonus points for having a night mode at any rate.

Mini Metro is by far one of my favourite games. You're given the challenge of building a metro system that successfully links people to the destinations of their choices without overwhelming the network or resulting in waiting too long at any one station. It's remarkably zen but also remarkably challenging... and I can't help but love to play this game!\n\nI particularly love the daily challenges which provide their own constraints but which can only be attempted once.

Mini Metro's distinct levels--all inspired by real-world metro lines--definitely have deep nuances that affect your tactics for each and reward your experimentation and practice.

It's a lot like Flight Control, except more complex.

I love the meditative, minimalist aesthetic, especially with Night Mode enabled. FEZ composer Disasterpeace has crafted a lush, warm, subdued soundscape full of soft sines and small clocks that grows, shrinks, or shifts dynamically in response to your actions based on conditions in the game. Though even at full volume on my laptop, it wasn't loud enough for me.

At their core, simulation and management games are about optimizing a particular workflow or mastering a certain system as best as you can. Mini Metro falls into that category, even loosely--just on a smaller, less permanent scale. I admit, a larger and lasting scale of some kind would be even more interesting here, but it shares these traits of starting all over" with both score-chaser Arcade games and procedurally-generated Roguelike games.

Yet even with all its depth and variations

reviewText:
It's exactly what it looks like: A minimalist puzzle game with a creative concept.

That's what you think it is, and you're very correct. The visuals say it all, and convey it all, in a manner that is easy to comprehend instinctively before you purchase. But let me expand on that.

The design also conveys information INSIDE the game, not just the trailer. That's important. This type of minimalistic puzzler shouldn't sell you on simplicity and then be hard to understand. Mini Metro does what it promises so clean and so clear that you'll be surprised. It's graceful.

In essence, you are free to draw a selection of colored lines between designate points (stations) along a map. When lines are connected, they allow a train car to move automatically from station to station. At each station are a number of small shapes building in a queue. When the train stops at a station, it unloads any shapes (passengers) it is currently carrying provided they match the shape of the station, then grabs the passengers at the station and carries them along its line.

This plays automatically for a few turns until new stations appear. Then you need more lines.

Soon you have too little carrying capacity and need more trains.

As you carry more and more people to their destination, you unlock upgrades that complicate the problem at hand without attaching complications to the mechanics. The additions are fluid. It keeps the experience tight and meditative, albeit a bit stressful because it's (mostly) in real time.

As you unlock new cities, the geography and use of tunnels/bridges come into play. Some levels have a faster train car, or a crazier population growth. Keep at it and you'll find yourself organically creating your own tricks: breaking down lines and moving them back and forth between overflowing stations over and over to create shorter paths for your trains, or pausing just so you can flip a train in the opposite rotation for one cycle. Every little decision can change your success.

This game works. It is fun.

If you've watched the trailer and read even a brief description you'll already know whether or not you like this type of experience. If you DO like it, then this will NOT disappoint you.
Fun puzzle game, different from what else is out there.

Fun, casual metro system planning and puzzle" game. Very minimalistic design choices based on metro and public transportation maps you see in big cities.\nDaily challanges and achievements keep this game going even after many hours of playing it."
Surprisingly addictive, easy to play but hard to master.
Relaxing and stressful at the same time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Mini Metro is a mini strategy puzzle game. The idea is to link up stations so commuters can get to there destination. The longer you are in the game the more demanding the commuters become and this is where you need to place you railway lines strategically.

The games concept is simple but can get difficult quickly. This makes each game you play short and sweet. It is fun and can be addictive, trying to better your high score each time.

The graphics are simple but effective for a game like this.

There is currently no sound however I believe that this is one of the things they are currently working on.

This game is no way complete and there are many things they need to add. However there is plenty to do for the price you play.

Highly recommend this game. The games are short depending on how good you get. Also the idea is simple, fun  and addictive.

reviewText: This is a wonderful, relaxing little puzzle game with an attractive, minimalist style to both its audio and visuals, and mechanics straightforward enough that the game never needs to explicitly spell them out for you. Despite the simplicity of the mechanics, though, this is a brainbender extraordinaire; those of you who enjoy setting up systems to work in the most efficient manner possible will have an absolute blast here.\n\nThe concept is simple: you're in control of the subway system. Stations open across the map gradually, and you need to connect them with different coloured lines. Stations have different shapes, and the shapes of the commuters" that appear at each station represent where they want to go. You will
recommended: need to plan out your routes so that there's minimal inefficiency; "circle" commuters will only ever want to go to "square" or "triangle" initially

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Mini Metro is a puzzle game about stringing up as many different shaped stations in a line as possible. The challenge comes from the imbalance and numerousness of the spawned shapes, and your task is to figure out the logistics of shipping any cargo to its desired type of destination as efficiently as possible, without overflowing its spawn station, or any interchange stations on the way.

The art style will be familiar to anyone who uses their local metro system, however unfortunately this game is not a simulator by any means. If you want to build any metro line in a way that vaguely resembles reality, you will lose and you will lose hard. The screenshots you see are only representative of the first 5 minutes of the game, they are not representative of anything you might end up with - There will never be enough lines or trains supplied to allow you to create anything orderly - your trains will weave around the map, twisting and turning to gobble up all un-connected stations like a nokia snake.

I would recommend this game to anyone who wants an interesting puzzle in a metro theme. However I have to downvote it because the description is misleading - If you're looking for a subway management simulator, look elsewhere.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been having a good time with this game, it is currently early in development and does not have any music yet. Great to play while listening to something. Each time you play you will get better at designing sound efficient systems. The leaderboards give incentive to improve yourself. I have only played this game as of this review for 5 hours and i can see myself playing it for a lot more.

It is very calm, and includes a night mode if you are not a fan of looking at a white screen the whole time. I can proudly say that for a few of the maps I am in the top 1000 best players, and I plan to do even better. Small decisions such as a new tunnel or line while small at firsst can mean a big difference.

I saw this game after watching a youtube video of it by the youtuber Sips and decided to jump on it due to its simple puzzle and strategy elements. You are able to pause it at any moment to restructure your stations and routes. I give this game a solid pat on the back so to speak. I am looking forward to the new maps.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Mini Metro looks like subway schema that came to movement. Its catchy visual style attracts unreservedly and dedicated to people keen on minimalism and infographic style.

Every day more and more people from different reigns need to get to different places. You as a head of new subway station will construct new ways to help them reach thies destinations. The quantity of peole in sybways is increasing, so you'll need to enlarge your web of tunnels. City department will help you with you task, and  on the beginning of new week you'll gain a bonus. It could be an additional vagon to existing train. Or you can purchase extra tunnels for establish underwater ways. Maybe, you'll need a new line for decrease an overload on existing branches.

So far, only survive" mode is available for now. How long will you support and reorganise your subway line before inevitable owerload (that leads to closure of all train branches) of human flow? I hope authors will make some new modes with obvious golas later.

Still
date: Mini Metro is a simple (but not easy) and neat puzzle logic game with pleasant appearance that gives enjoyable pastime"
hoursPlayed: true
helpfulPercent: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, it's not a real transportation task.  Passengers indiscriminate the destination station as long as it matches their shape.  Usually most stations are circle shaped, triangle and square stations are less and then there are these 3 or 4 uniquely-shaped (cross, pentagon etc.) stations that force you to interconnect all lines.

Also it's not a metro building game.  Underground tunnels with railways can be created instantly out of thin air and as easily removed should the need arise.  With time progress the stations appear randomly on the city map and this sometimes requires total rearrangement of the graphs.

It's an intriguing puzzle game that can be played for short durations.  Instant satisfaction, high replayability, nice colour palette, very smooth feeling from the animations.  IMHO it's worth around five bucks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I haven't been lured to write any game review till date, but I couldn't resist the urge to express how I feel about this game in specific. Although from a scale point of view, Mini Metro is probably one of the smallest games I have ever played, but this game will give you an amount of addiction time" mega scale games can't compete with!

Mini Metro get's you hooked on little things with very deep and addicting strategy addiction. Being able to play a strategy game with little things such is very rewarding. Things like
a) How should I divide my routes
b) Which stations should I create connections
c) Should I increase carriage or lines
d) which stations should connect to which lines

I am a fan of large scale strategy games from Sim Cities to Tycoons to Business Sims
recommended: minimalist yet very enjoyable game gives you instant joy without needing to wait ages for results of your strategic decisions. This is extremely valuable if you are a busy person and don't have time to play games that need hours for things to shape up!\n\nIf you like strategy games and would like to get a chance of playing strategy games in casual mode
hoursPlayed: I don't thing anything can currently beat Mini Metro. Absolutely wonderful!"

reviewText: A masterpiece of design. Clean, simple, elegant, easy to learn, and yet hard to master (try getting into the top 10% on every level). Not more than it has to be nor less, it as close to perfect in the execution of this design concept as can probably be achieved. The only criticism I can level against the game is the randomness of the choices between days. Sometimes you just don't get any 'tunnel luck.' Also the music and sound are pleasant at first, but as the game runs long it can layer into an annoying dishormony of sounds. Overall I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
EH.

I played it a bit, and I can definitely see the appeal, but this game isn't for me.  Each level starts off easy, but quickly spirals out of control. The game tosses in new points and people for your network to accomodate, and though the growth rate of the network accelerates, your rate of aquiring assets does not. What's worse, is that I kept feeling like I just wanted it to pause for a minute so I could figure out if I was doing things right, but it grinds reletlessley forward withough giving you time to think.  I guess what I miss the most is a chance to learn and improve, but each round gets so out of hand that I don't have time to learn what I'm doing wrong. I suppose enough trial and error would get me there, but I like a game that gives me a ramp to climb instead of expecting me to fail my way through.

If you dig quick games, and you enjoy hectic game play, then this may be the game for you. It's easy to learn and hard to master, and the interface is nice on the eyes. The audio ties into the actions occuring on screen, which got old quick for me, but others seem to really dig it. There's multiple game modes, and many levels.

All in all, I suspect that this is a great game that I happen to have no taste for. Though others seem to love it, I don't think I'll be reccomending it to any of my friends.

reviewText: I have less than two hours of gameplay in this and I've already seen everything there is to do.  I wasn't expecting too much, but was still disappointed by the lack of gameplay ;  you will be spending much more time looking at the game than interacting with it.  At a certain point it turns very suddenly from a laid back and easy game to an overwhelming and impossible race against the passengers, which may have been an intentional mechanic by the developer to end the game before the player notices that there's nothing more to do.  Unfortunately the endless play mode ruins this concept and makes it very obvious that there isn't much left to see. This game is very beautifully designed and has a relaxing soundtrack so it would have been a good purchase at a fraction of its price, but for $10 I was really expecting much more than I got.\n\nWhile this game looks appealing, don't buy it if you're expecting any more than an hour of entertainment.  If you're going to get it, wait for a sale and you'll get a better deal.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an interesting little game which is still in development at time of writing but is definitely worth a play!

The aim of the game is to create an efficient network of subway stations, so as not to allow a build up of waiting passengers at any one place.

The difficulty of the game increases the longer that it is played, allowing it to maintain a level of difficulty even when you think that you have figured out the best way to plan your network, this keeps the game playable for longer. Each time you start a game the initial nodes are randomised so no two games are identical.

There are three different modes to play the game in thus far:
Normal - Don't let the stations overcrowd
Endless - Aim for the most efficient network
Extreme - Lines cannot be changed once placed


If you want a game to fill a fifteen minute gap this could be for you.
If you want a stratagy game which will keep you playing for a little longer, this could also be for you.

Early Access Review

The game is basically about moving passengers from one station to the next, by using public transportation. You decide where these lines go, how they are connected and how many vehicles and carriages there are on each line. Every game starts you off softly, and get increasingly difficult as time passes. At the end of each week in the game, you recieve bonuses. Pick wisely ;)

I bought this at a sale and have never regretted it. Knowing what i know now, i wouldn't mind paying full price for it either. It's a gem of a small time waster. One which i wholeheartedly reccomend to everyone who think they might be interested in this game.

10/10 Excellent game for what it tries to be.

reviewText:
A puzzle game about building a highly abstracted mass transit system - there is no “solution” to the puzzles, just the question of how long you can keep meeting an ever rising demand.

I admire both the aesthetic and pacing of this game.

The interface is beautifully minimal, both providing everything you need to understand and play the game while evoking the classic topological underground map.

The pacing is well executed with periods of calm where you feel in control, followed by periods of frantic activity as new stations and special stations force rapid change across your network.

So why haven’t I played it more?

Access to the depth - I don’t think the game lacks meaningful choices; when I look at the scores people have achieved (more than doubling my best on my most played cities) there are clearly things I can do to improve.  However the game progression doesn’t challenge me to discover new strategies or provide the signposts to improvement in the same way that my favourite puzzle games do.

Well worth a look but don't be too shocked if the initial rush expires after 8-10 hours

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yeah this is a pretty solid puzzler that is in Early Access. Even though there is no music, and limited features, I certainly will get my money's worth here (6.99$). Really solid gameplay mechanic that is easy to learn and probably near-impossible to master. Great minimalistic design aesthetic with addicting gameplay. The developer's also seem in-tune with the community, and really, what they claim they will add does not seem that far from what they already have in place.

If there was a transport sim rogue-like, this may be it. It has:

-Random depot spawns
-I believe (Random) spot along the river where the focus starts
-RPG-like leveling up via weekly upgrade choices and resource management
-Permadeath
-The ability to pauses and make decisions is not *quite* turn-based, but damned close
-Ability to solve goals using different strategies (high complexity)
-Player vs. world

There is not:
-Fantasy elements
-Grid-based

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Strategic tube/subway system simulator, with a minimalist art style.

Develop the Metro system of 10 real world cities, starting from 3 stations and steadily increasing by random, for up until one overflows. Each week you are given a choice of upgrades to choose from, and the upgrade you choose can make or break your tube system.

Across 3 different game modes, and the newly implemented Daily Challenges, Mini Metro is an excellent casual game to spend half an hour on each day.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really like the concept but unfortunately that’s all it feels like right now: a concept – not even a working beta. I can’t recommend this because it really feels like nothing more than a web-browser game. It is still open beta and it is only like $6 but still I wouldn’t pay $6 for a flash game.
Aside from things clearly still in development like sound, more levels, a bunch of options and stuff like that, there’s just no meat to the game. Essentially all you’re doing is dragging lines between dots on the screen not unlike the zillion air traffic controller clones for mobiles. While I’m looking for casual as opposed to a transport simulator, it still needs more to feel like a game. How about currency, pricing, upgradables, a map that zooms out and enlarges as the game progresses, etc.?
Don’t get me wrong, the game is fun and super addicting for like 5 or less hours. After that however, there’s just nothing else to do. If you can accept this and have a couple of dollars to burn, go for it. If you are neurotic and have to do simple repetitive tasks to maximize efficiency, play away. If you are looking some actual content or something more than your average free mobile game, I wouldn’t bother.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Minimalist, conceptually fun transport strategy game, but very buggy and badly designed. Can't accomplish anything with strategy when you spend literally all your time fighting the horrible route interface and the arbitrary, random, nonsensical design decisions that make the game more of a time waster where success is based as much on luck as on skill. I read several strategy guides and managed to make headway in the game, eventually beating all the basic level goals, but it was never enjoyable in any way because the game is so fundamentally broken and badly designed. I prefer strategy games, not luck based time wasters. The game has no sound and I literally had more fun listening to my Solar Fields ambient trance albums in the background than I did playing the game.

Some examples:

Metro lines frequently refuse all attempts to revise their route for absolutely no reason unless you chop out the ENTIRE line and remake it. This is a huge headache and by itself makes the game unplayable when the randomness requires adaptation. I know you can click the route near a station and then drag over the station to remove that section of the route -- I'm saying that sometimes it simply doesn't work, and for no reason that I can discern. EDIT 6/19/2015 - This was fixed in the last patch

New stations spawn randomly (you cannot build stations) and often in places that make level goals inaccessible (e.g. Carry 1000 passengers using only 1 tunnel" but then new stations keep spawning between 2 rivers and long before the map opens up to give you more route options). Or how about the Hong Kong level goal: Move 1100 passengers with only 8 stations per line. Sounds reasonable
date: until you recognize that stations often spawn INTO your routes and instantly ruin your entire game on the spot. Or Berlin where you must carry the same huge number of passengers using only 1 locomotive per line. What's that? You say the end of week choices didn't offer you another line to run your end of week locomotive on? Too bad. Hit restart
hoursPlayed: maybe next time you'll get luckier.\n\nPassengers often accumulate at a station with multiple empty trains passing by regularly without picking them up for absolutely no reason (connecting lines properly placed to destination
voteText: sometimes destination was even on the same line!) and this is yet more hair pulling insanity because within 30 seconds or so of passengers not being picked up at a station it's BLAM GAME OVER because the game ends the instant people have to wait too long for a train pickup. Why? I have no idea. That's just what the developer chose. Several times I got Game Over despite clearing the passengers out of the station just before the timer ran out. I don't know why.\n\nThere seems to be no fundamental locational supply and demand for stations (it's all random) and only a tenuous connection between time of day and passenger movements
helpfulPercent: if there IS any connection. I get that the different geometry icons and the way they evolve independent of the player is designed to simulate a city economy moving and the metro having to adapt to changing demand but in practise the implementation is so scattered
votesTotal: and random that it makes no sense and is the antithesis of fun to have to deal with. Real world metrorail transport doesn't work this way. Combine this with all the other interface headaches and you'll likely be passionately hating the game before you get too far.\n\nThese fundamental problems make the game generally unplayable
votesFunny: unenjoyable
commentsCount: and outright annoying
column16:
and I could not possibly recommend this pile of disasterous development and unsound design. The fact that the game has no sound has no bearing on the final verdict. It's just bad.

---------------
UPDATE 6/19/2015
I've played this game several more hours and beat all the maps since I wrote this review and I still feel essentially the same. A patch removed the problem with track route not changing but the more I play the more I realize that the main game mode (not endless or extreme) is based almost entirely on luck of the draw with you predestined to fail sooner or later. To get the goals and unlock the extreme modes you have to have some combination of lucky starting position
column18: and lucky end week choices. Sure
column19: you need good planning and careful manipulation of the routes on top of that as well
column20: but do you really want to play a game that force fails you based on luck no matter how skilled you are? I don't. I still don't recommend this game unless you like wasting time. It's a decent time waster

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love casual games, but I have to say this game is really boring. I know I haven't put much time in it, but that is because I got bored really quickly.

This game feels like a more boring version of Pipe Dreams"
date:
which for the younger crowd is a game where you have to build a piping system before liquid would flow and points were rewarded for the length of pipe the water traveled through before flooding out of the pipes.

I digress. This game is about setting up a "metro" system to pick up shapes and deliver them to a station of the same shape. While you are setting up your "tracks" new shapes randomly appear as well as patrons. Those shapes have to be integrated into your system before the patrons get frustrated and leave at which point you lose.

The bigger problem I have with this game is that there is no way of planning your system as the shape locations appear at random. There is a way to restructure your system but the interface feels unintuitive and I'm never sure if when I remove tracks/trams that they return to my inventory. From what I can tell - trams do not - and therefore you are punished for a restructure that you couldn't have planned before.

This game feels like a mobile game
recommended: best experienced on the crapper.\n\nI hesitate to say this game is horrible as it has many great reviews
hoursPlayed: but as a fan of casual games - you can skip this one. Sorry devs.\n\nI will give this game more time and if my opinion changes I will update this review."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game thinking it would be a nice way to spend my Sunday afternoon/evening with a bit of a brain puzzle, based on all of the good reviews here.

The game only kept me entertained for 29 minutes.  I know the game is supposed to mimic the look of a transit map, but the plain, flat, minimalistic shapes were really boring to look at.  Did not at all put me in mind of moving people from place to place.  These type of visuals might work much better on a mobile device than on a full PC display.

I was frustrated that I could not choose the type of upgrade I needed at some points.  When I needed tunnels, it only offered me lines and locomotives.  When I needed lines, it only offered my tunnels and carriages.

Trains seemed to drive by passengers for no good reason - train was not full, and destination stop was only one or two stations down the track.  This really affected playability negatively at higher levels.

Maybe in a few more iterations this might be fun, but not yet...

Alright. So this game is straightfowarldy AWESOME.

If you expect a hardcore, uber-realistic metro/railway sim - that's not your game, definetly. If you're in for some relaxation... well... maaybe.

Generally, what are you going to do while playing this game is trying to fix everything, while it all goes to HELL. Seriously) Mini Metro always starts on a fairly slow pace, but then picks up... And suddenly you're knee deep in  ♥♥♥♥  overcrowded stations, juggling trains from lane to lane and desperatly struggling to save the day, while new stations keep popping at the places you least want them to spawn at.

The stations are commonly Circle, Triangle and Square. The uniques being Gem, Diamond, Plus, Pizza shaped thing, star and a few more.

Early Access Review

Just a crazy simple, beautiful, extremely polished strategy game.

Place metro lines to connect stations that randomly appear as you play.  That's basically it.  You have a limited number of lines, a limited number trains and cars to place on your lines, and a limited number of tunnels to cross water, each of which you recieve more of as you play.  You can place and delete and rearrange your lines and trains as much as you want for no cost (and there is a tactical pause).  All you have to do is keep getting polygonal people to their polygonal destinations smoothly as long as you can, while the number of stations and passengers keeps increasing.

Although the game is still in early access, this is really an incredibly polished game (the only thing missing is sound, which I don't mind).  It looks clean an modern and beautiful, it has a lovely UI and menu system... it's extremely clear and easy to use.  I've spent several hours playing it so far, and I definitely intend to play more... it is a great casual game - easy to pick up, with short self-contained sessions - but it also has some real depth.  You can put a lot of thought into your metro designs, or you can just throw something down and watch what happens.  It's quite flexible in terms of ways to play.  Each map/level/city also offers unique constraints and layouts (semi randomized each time of course), and the difficulty of the levels ranges from hold-my-hand to crushingly difficult, giving you access to all of them immediately, so you can explore your ability and comfort level from the beginning, and aspire to those harder cities.

The only negative thing I can think of to say about the game is that I wouldn't want to sit and play it for hours straight.  It's more of a pick-up put-down game.  Also, there is no tutorial, and while the UI is relatively straight forward, understanging the princples of the game might take you a couple minutes and/or google searches.  Hopefully a tutorial will be added soon :)

Highly recommended!  I think this has a lot of appeal for a lot of different types of people.

I'm impressed and very much enjoy playing this game.  I recommend it for those that enjoy tactical games, and aren't married to the idea that tactical games have to be combat-related.  Great fun.

Early Access Review\n\nThis game is very simple and is worth every single penny. The game at the moment has no audio. The aim of the game is to keep your transport system fluent. If stations are crowded the game will end. The game features in several different cities. At the end of the week you will get a locomotive and 2 tunnels/carriage or line. At the start its best to make sure the most common stops like(circle,triangle,square). This will prevent transferring passengers from one place to another. Holding passengers is a bad idea as it just makes the stations more crowded. The map its self looks like the London Underground map by Harry Beck. Please consider that you will need to do some self learning. My first try wasnt bad but i slowly got better.

Alright. So this game is straightfowarldy AWESOME.

If you expect a hardcore, uber-realistic metro/railway sim - that's not your game, definetly. If you're in for some relaxation... well... maaybe.

Generally, what are you going to do while playing this game is trying to fix everything, while it all goes to HELL. Seriously) Mini Metro always starts on a fairly slow pace, but then picks up... And suddenly you're knee deep in  ♥♥♥♥  overcrowded stations, juggling trains from lane to lane and desperatly struggling to save the day, while new stations keep popping at the places you least want them to spawn at.

Sounds horrible - but it delivers almost heaven-like feeling of peace and enjoyment. Don't believe me? Try out the free demo on devs' site, it does pretty much develop it.

The design is genuine. A masterpiece, a pure delight for eyes. Hope developers would come up with some decent music to match it (some ambient, maybe?), otherwise half the game experience would be ruined ;(

Each playthrough starts out perfectly innocently.  It's reassuring.  Almost boring.  A little voice in the back of my head tells me that I'm laying foundations for what will come next, and that it's important to get this right, but the ease of redesigning my entire system at this point in the game tells me that the voice is lying.  The week ends, I get a new locomotive, and choose one of options to go with it.

Somehow, by week five, my nice, neat train system has started to turn into a spider's-web of cross-connections and long loops.  I need to add a new station to the main loop, which means disconnecting three stations, then reconnecting them in a different sequence.  Of course, now that I've done that, it should reduce the pressure on that line and mean that I'm dropping passengers off more often, which should improve the overall capacity.  Unfortunately, I didn't notice a new station opening up on the other side of the map, and it's critically overcrowded.  Game over.

Mini Metro is a roguelike action-puzzle game where the central mechanic is designing a train network.  It's trickier than it looks, and if it gets its strangely compelling hooks into you, it may drive you insane.  Enough time wasted - I need to fire it back up and see if I can work out a better way of dealing with those annoying suburban regions where nobody wants to get off, and everybody wants to get on....

Early Access Review

Just when you thought you had it under control... Another bloody circle station appears...
Mini Metro is where you're in charge or a city's transportation. People need to get going. You're the one in charge. You can't screw up. Mini Metro is where things can escalate within a matter of minutes. You'll have about 3 lines connecting to 5 or so stations and then you'll have some strange trickery of loops and squiggles of so-called train lines.

There are the ocassional bugs that appear rarely, but notable. When you have a train with more than 8 carriages *i know...*, it can teleport when you've redrawn a line that completely exposes it's temporary line. So basically, when you redraw the track so much so that your train is off the newly drawn track, the train will teleport to the nearest station that the newly drawn line is connected to.

Now, of course, this is in Early Access. So, I'm telling you right now, get the game. For $7, it's worth every cent. 10/10, would buy again.

This game is however a nice little puzzle game with a very recognisable art style and play style. The plain and simple idea being build a rail system by dragging lines to appearing stations. The stations start of very few and far between and are represented by different shapes and above each station appear smaller black shapes. Those are your passengers the shape of them show where they want to get to, Simple yes? .. no. This is where the games puzzle" element comes to play. Each person wants to get to specefic stations and you want to get them there so you join up stations with lines and make a lovely little picture

Early Access Review

There's something inherently calming about joining the dots and creating order - and Mini Metro capitalises on this beautifully. Gorgeous, minimal and uncluttered design, lovely bright colours and simple shapes are the order of the day. Shaped stations pop up on the white landscape, requiring you to join them together with lines. As you do, passengers appear at them, demanding to get to other stations.

The system that deals with moving passengers about, especially when to and when not to pick them up and which interchanges to drop them at seems, even in this 'early access' build, to be flawless. Short of the missing sound and music (which I can't wait for) and the so-called Scenic and Rush Hour modes (which seem to be Zen and Extreme in the version I have here) this is already a fantastic little game. Bonus points for having a night mode as well.

For fear of cluttering up the minimalism I'd like to be able to name stops  for my own reference or just for fun, but otherwise, I can't wait for the last finishing touches.

Early Access Review

A classic game in the making. Having played only an hour and a half at the moment I can see myself loosing much more time to this game.

While the lack of music is sad, being Early Access, I can't wait for the soundtrack to be added on.

All in all, this is no train sim, it is a frustratingly fun strategists dream which challenges your abilities each time you play through and there is no forgiveness for even the slightest oversight. That being said, I would have liked a little tutorial that would have explained that when a new station appears on an existing line it becomes a place where trains blissfully roll by. Therefore, you must either redraw the entire line to include the new station or add it to another line.

Graphically, the simplistic design is really quite beautiful and as time goes on you start to admire the mess of lines that begin to splay out as you try to balance length of lines and coverage.

All in all, a great game and I highly recommend picking this game up while it is at a very reasonable price.

On a lighter note, I now take my hat off to every Transport Minister past and present.

Early Access Review

There's something inherently calming about joining the dots and creating order - and Mini Metro capitalises on this beautifully. Gorgeous, minimal and uncluttered design, lovely bright colours and simple shapes are the order of the day. Shaped stations pop up on the white landscape, requiring you to join them together with lines. As you do, passengers appear at them, demanding to get to other stations.

The system that deals with moving passengers about, especially when to and when not to pick them up and which interchanges to drop them at seems, even in this 'early access' build, to be flawless. Short of the missing sound and music (which I can't wait for) and the so-called Scenic and Rush Hour modes (which seem to be Zen and Extreme in the version I have here) this is already a fantastic little game. Bonus points for having a night mode as well.

For fear of cluttering up the minimalism I'd like to be able to name stops  for my own reference or just for fun, but otherwise, I can't wait for the last finishing touches.

Early Access Review

If you're looking for a difficult-to-master strategy game, this is pretty solid. If, however, you're looking for a mass transit sim ... this is not it.

Once you figure out key elements of maximizing efficiency, you begin to realize that the real-world logic behind the layout of the world's metros need not apply. Thinking of a radial design enclosed by a circle line? It'll only last if the sequence of shapes makes sense. Ultimately that's where the game lost its 'sim' appeal for me.

Nevertheless it's a satisfying puzzler that can embrace many different tactical approaches.

Early Access Review

Mini Metro is one of those games that you think will be easy to play and your line will thrive. Although it soon becomes apparent that the task is huge. Each new station that appears, is another problem you have to deal with. You have to manage your resources well to keep your line open. At the end of each round you recieve bonuses like a new train, an additional line or carriage. You decide which, choose wisely or you may just be making your own downfall.
You don't need to be a seasoned gamer to get to grasps with this amazing game. Although it's in Early Access, you can see how the game will shape and find new ways to captivate you. The recent addition of Zen Mode keeps you expanding your line for the ultimate Metro.
What I love most about this game is that you can not win, only survive the hustle and bustle of the stations for as long as your, hopefully, well planned lines will allow it. The game is aesthetically pleasing - They use the classic coloured lines; like you would see on a metro map. You watch your map expand in realtime as you add more to it.
How long can you survive?

Early Access Review

If you are looking for a deep management game, this is not it.
If you are looking for an intricate transport tycoon follow up game, this is not it.
If you are looking for fancy graphics, this is not it.
However, if you are looking for a fun puzzler that'll keep you on your toes with reasonable pressure, simple and clean presentation, easy to grasp concept and lots of replayability, this is one of the best games you can get. And if you don't want to be pressurized by the game, you can play the Zen mode, which is a great relaxing timewaster. Simple, clean, intuitive, it's a great way to waste a few hours without even realizing said hours are gone. Bonus points if you are a fan of metro systems, but that isn't required to enjoy this game.
Special props to the devs, who are on top of the community and communicate with their customers a lot during the current stage of the game.

Early Access Review

I love this game! For an early access game, this is very polished and well done, with simplistic graphics and a concept that is easy to learn, but practice and different techniques are required to get a high score.

PROS:
+Nice graphics
+Good gameplay mechanics
+Fun to play
+Difficulty scales with time played in one game
+Easy to learn

CONS:
-Some bugs with changing paths of a train
-Not many levels (But it is in early access, so this is excusable)
-Not much variation in strategies between levels

WHAT I WOULD LIKE TO SEE IN FUTURE VERSIONS:
•Customizable levels with steam marketplace
•A mode where you can't ever lose the game
•Less shapes come in the night, and a burst at rush hour
•Randomized levels
•A mode where only the overcrowded places get shut down, and tracks can't run through them
•A mode where you are placed in a world where the stations are already placed, you have to connect them, and you run a simulation where you see how long it would last

This game is solid, I would recommend this game to anyone who wants a game that doesn't require a giant manual to get started, and wants a fun game.

Early Access Review

A really fun game you would expect on mobile devices but actually runs on windows/mac computers.

It is so simple to understand what to do, yet to get a good score you need to manage all your resources and build your map style metro systems in just the right way to keep the city moving. If you let a station overcrowd though, it is game over.

If you want lots of content for your money, I wouldn't buy this game as it doesn't have too much content yet, but what do you expect from an early access game. And still, it is only € 6,99 (do your conversion to $ or £ yourself).

I'd recommend this game if you want to play a game when you are bored, at work or at school, or just at home.

Quick note for the devs: It might just be the crappy mac I am on, but the game seems to lag a bit on highest speed in the end game on the efficiency gamemode (infinite time)

Early Access Review\n\nThis game has a truly special design. Early Access Review\n\nBoth cohesive and pleasing to the eye, this train game is not just another train game. reviewText:

Early Access Review

I just got back from work and, having barely kicked off my shoes, I went to play another round of Mini Metro. Then I noticed I have clocked over 100 hours in the two weeks that I have had this game. It is sucking my soul the way a game hasn't done since I was too young to have anything better to do than play games anyways. Now, admittedly, a portion of those hours are from me passing out with the game open, contemplating the overall efficiency of my entire subway system having been thrown a curve-ball station or two. But the difference between 100 hours total and 80 hours conscious is really not that significant, relative to overwhelming number of 0.6hrs-played games in my library. I don't normally write reviews, but I know there are casual gamers out there with similar disappointments, so this review is for you.

tl:dr : Casual, strategic gamers that like to watch their decisions unfold in as perfect a manner as they can conclude, get this game! Even (especially) in Early Access!

Review:
I forgot this game was Early Access until I came to this page to write the review, and that's a good thing! Most of us have been victimized by vaporware, and I understand your hesitation to trust it (or really anything on steam anymore), such that our reviews are the only information worth sifting through anymore.

Mini Metro is a minimalist game both visually and in its core mechanics. That being said, it does both of these things so well and uniquely, even and its current state, that it seems more polished than a large portion of the released titles that just keep pumping out. And, although I yearn for more maps (when are we ever truly satisfied), the game feels complete enough that if it went full release today, I would clock another 100 hourse easily. The only thing it's missing is sound, but that's on the list to be added and ultimately the silence doesn't really detract from the game, playing my own moodscapes in the background. I'm sure there's more content that they plan to add, but I haven't been following the devs enough to tell you what those are. And honestly, bilissfully ignorant of their promises, I can tell that any new content is just going to be a wonderful surprise as the game progresses out of Early Access, such as the newly added Rush Hour Mode (more on that later). Also what I can't tell you is how fast the game is being updated. I got this game only recently, and in that time they updated with the addition of a whole new mode, but I may have just lucked out on my timing - look to other reviews or follow the devs for this info.

At its heart, Mini Metro is a game where you create a subway (or metro depending on your colloquialism) system that is as efficient as possible at delivering passengers between stations.

I had gotten 1/4 the way into my original review, which was on the way to being pretty fleshed out I thought, but then I learned there is a charlimit when writing reviews. So, it's sorta lost it's cohesion but I hope I got most of my love for this game out.

Stations are also abstract and minmalistic, being represented by bordered geometric shapes. All maps start you with a Circle, Square, and Triangle station, and represent the most common stations you'll see. Having no depth of explanation, it's difficult to call those stations by anything other than their shapes, only learning to conceptualize the different types as things like transfers and major stations once you learn how the stations need to be connected to be efficient later in the game. That being said, you often have to use stations as a matter of efficiency that betrays your concepts of them. This is one of the things I find special about Mini Metro. You can know the rules in and out, but your understanding of their roles changes with every new station that pops up, creating a logic of efficiency that is more conscious and fulfilling than simply figuring out the math.

There is no right or wrong decision (except for Rush Hour mode) as everything you've done on the map so far can be freely and meticulously readjusted instantaneously. The few resources the game limits you with like the number of trains and bridges, when not in use, are returned to your pool of resources with zero loss; you can only get more, and will need more. Even lategame when you're struggling to keep 20-30 stations efficient as a whole, a few clicks and you can wipe the board of your entire subway for a fresh start, but without a restart back to silly ol' 3 stations. Casual, no need to dredge through a game you just played a second time to get to a point where you can use what you learned the first time, you can just continually build on your knowledge.

It's actually those lategame board clears that, personally, are the most fun for me. As you progress on a map, you'll get extra trains. I only ever use one train on a line. This is extremely limiting, but I enjoy the challenge of the game that way, because without a second train to pick up the slack, lines have to be more efficient at interacting with eachother, dropping off passengers in perfect spots, running cross-track or parallel to alleviate congestion, balancing short but heavily loaded lines with long but easily resolved ones. And a board clear of infrastructure allows me to consider an efficient system as a whole instead of one in relation to what I had built already. This is normally where I pass out staring at my screen.

Game Modes, since I'm not sure I've seen a review for since Rush Hour came out:
The game has three modes currently, Commuter (skirmish), Scenic (peaceful), and  new Rush Hour (permabuild).
The difference between Commuter mode and Scenic mode is mosty just that if you aren't being efficient enough on a Commuter map, your passengers pile up and get mad that they're stting in a station too long, you'll fail.

Rush Hour is the bane of my existence. Most of what I have described is in the two modes where you can readjust your lines and resources. In Rush Hour mode, once you connect two stations, you can't unconnect them. You can extend their lines to new stations, but then you're stuck with that order of stations. Trains move down the line from one station to another, and then turn around and do the opposite order (unless you loop them). Because of this, in any game mode, adding a new station to the line affects its overall efficiency by first simply making the people at one end of the line wait longer for the train to get back, secondly because if passengers aren't getting dropped off efficiently, your train gets full and he passes by stations of people already waiting. Even extra trains, when placed, can't be picked back up. The only saving grace to this mode is that while in the other modes, stations just simply appear and you have to deal with them accordingly. In Rush Hour mode, you get to see where and what type the next station will be. I have not spent more than a few minutes in this mode as it requires a completely different mindset than the way I play the other two modes.

For $7 at regularly priced Early Access, probably the most appropriately priced item I've bought on Steam.

10/10 Would connect the dots for 100 more hours with even the smallest of a content boost.

Very fun puzzle game that represents a masterpiece of simplicity.

It provides a very cerebral challange because there are so many possibilities and strategies, and all of them have advantages and disadvantages. You find yourself constantly trying to figure out the best way of planning. There is a great deal of strategy for such a simple concept.

Not yet fully developed, but even in its current state it's fantastic. At present, there is no music and are no win conditions, but if you put on your own music it can be such a cozy atmosphere, and the lack of win condition, similar to tetris (it just gets harder and harder until you lose), provides a really addictive need to create an even better system.

Simple to play, difficult to master, impossible to put down. Can't wait to see the final product.

This game is one of the simplest yet best quick little challenge/strat/thinking/brainpower ect games I have played. you get stressed a bit, not to the point of a mental breakdown but just enough to make it entertaining. As this is early access I will be talking more aboult the con's than the pro's to help the curators along.

cons:
1 why doesn't it open in full screen in the first place. pretty much every body i know would put this in full screen, it is just more sensible.

2 it didnt seem to auto adjust to the res this was annoying until i found you could change the res and fine tune it.

3 the bar at the bottom was not obvious in daytime mode, and would be better if the handle was a different colour. Also i feel it should start locked so that new players can find it easily (like me)

4 there aren't adjustable intensities. slowing down the rate at which people" spawn would be nice for when you're tired and don't want to play on a full out fps and dont want the full stress of what it is now. options like "slow" "casual" "normal" "hard" "intense" would be great. if there are these they are not obvious.

5 night time is WAAAAYYYYY better than day time and this option should be easier to find.

6 changing line shapes can be annoying sometimes i had to completley undo a line to fit in just 1 more station. to be able to break the line at any station would be great

That is all the cons I can think of so just remember that I focused on the cons. The gameplay is awesome even if it is very simple and is very addicting. It loads quickly which is awesome. it is nice and bright. it is simple enough to play when tired. and just get it. you will be addicted. AND ITS CHEAP AS CHIPS. All around an awesome game and I can see it really becoming something as it progresses."

This is a great little game, a simple to learn strategy/puzzle game that has that whole one more go" aspect.

All you need to do is link your different stations together and make sure the stations don't get too busy.  Yes you'll earn extra trains
date: extra carriages and extra lines.  But the whole game still comes down to the simple goal of linking your stations together.   You start with three stations and it seems an overly easy task but as the station start to increase so too does the difficulty and you find your metro system falling apart as you try to figure out the best way to connect them all.\n\nThankfully there's the option to hit Pause

This game can be summed up in a two words.

Frustratingly Awesome.

THe idea behind it is to create a mini metro network between stations, or shapes as they are in this game, and deliver the right shapes to their respective stations. The shapes will change trains, from one line to another until they reach their destination.

You can stretch your lines aslong as you want, but be warned, doing so will decrease your abiltiy to collect passengers quickly as each line is limited to four trains.

The challenge of the game is great, having to wait till the end of the week to top up your supplies is very challenging, especially when you get close to having all 8 lines running, those extra carriages can be lifesavers.

I highly recommend this game, and if it can get any better Im eagerly awaiting the full release from the developers.

Early Access Review

This game is simple yet addicitvily effective, if you are looking for something that you can spend 30mins - 1 hour playing to fill a small gap in your day then look no further. The game is brilliant, painfully cruel at times but always leaves you with the feeling of hopefully one day you may catch a break and beat your high score.

The graphics are great, really smooth and clean. I especially liked night time feature which darkens everything for you if you are playing a night and don't want to be blinded by a bright white screen.

All in all a great little game and I would happy recommend.

Early Access Review

I'm not really sure what it is about this little indie game, but seriously, if the subject matter interests you at all, then I recommend you pick it up.

It is, by far, one of the most compulsively playable titles I have set my hands on in quite some time. Even though it resides in the early access areas of Steam, it can comfortably sit beside others that are deemed to be finished. The only thing missing from this game is sound. That being said, the sound is something I couldn't care less about. It is the least of my concern as I continue to further the efficiency and optimal layout of my subway lines.

The game itself is played through various stages, in this case, cities of the world. Each stage provides you with a basic layout map and routes or lines" to place between stations. The stations are represented as shapes on the map that you must connect using your lines. As you do so additional symbols are shown on the map to represent the passengers.   Your locomotives move around the map autonomously along your set routes picking up and dropping off passengers as they go. This would present itself as an easy puzzle to solve
recommended: as the days and weeks go by in game
hoursPlayed: that couldn't be farther from the truth. It becomes a complex balancing act to try to get passengers to and fro as quickly as possible without allowing them to build up at an individual stations. This
voteText: as far as I can tell
helpfulPercent: is the only end game state. If a station has too many passengers
votesHelpful: the countdown begins until finally the game notifies you of your defeat.\n\nThe game is so simple and elegant
votesTotal: yet complex and harsh
votesFunny: all at the same time. I haven't played anything like it before. It sits by itself in a world of indie games that are increasinging in quality all the time
commentsCount: yet somehow all have a familiar feeling. This eschews that familiarity for something altogether different. Something playable

column20: but it will no doubt allow you to get a taste of things for yourself. I don't think you'll be disappointed.\n\nHighly recommended!  10/10"

Early Access Review

It's simply amazing, for short that is. But really it is, amazing. The simplistic and minimalistic 2D artstyle is really nice. The way the game works is overwhelmingly good to be in an Early Access stage. The first few ingame days are quite simple while the further on you get in the game the harder it gets, more clutter with more stations, lines and locomotives. The stress gets real in this game.

Really good game. If you haven't already bought the game I recomend you do so now.

Early Access Review\n\nA relaxing, simple game that really makes you have to think. Well done. The only thing I would change is to make the number of lines a variable to make the game easier or harder.

Early Access Review

This game is pretty addicting! It's fun to expand and dynamically create stategies to make your metro lines more efficient, The game needs no explanation as it's pretty self-explanitory, shapes want to go to that station and the train will take them there. The art-style and design is very clean and polished, the menu is pleasing in the same manner.

The only thing I can suggest for the future versions of this game is a map generator and creator, the game does feel small in the sense that only a few select cities are available. A ledgend to show what lines have what locomotives and cars would help organize things when the map populates with more stations.

Early Access Review\n\nEasy to learn and easy to love. Mini Metro is so simple that instructions aren't necessary; just click and drag. Simple enough, right? Well, wait until you have to choose between another rail line or a carriage. Wait until you run out of tunnels and cannot cross bodies of water. Wait until your stations start overflowing. Each round brings its own unique challenges, and it is very fulfilling to complete them. The art in Mini Metro is simple, yet it works perfectly with the game (and would now seem strange if it were presented any other way). I am excited to see future versions with music and more maps.
